description: From French termite, which is from Latin termites (three syllables), plural of termes.
Also possibly a derivation from Proto-Indo-European *term- (“drill”).

entries.meaning: A white-bodied, wood-consuming insect of the infraorder Isoptera, in the order Blattodea.
examples: Linnæus describes this insect under the Latin name of Termes; and citizen Cuvier speaks of it under that of Termites. The vulgar call it by that of white ant, or fourmi vaguevague. The termites divide themselves into societies: each society builds itself a next, and each nest belongs to an innumerable quantity of these insects, who acknowledge for their chiefs a king and a queen.

verbs.description: termite (third-person singular simple present termites, present participle termiting, simple past and past participle termited)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a chimpanzee: to catch termites by inserting a stick or vine into their nest and waiting for them to climb up it.
